trans-unit.source: Contributing to PowerShell Documentation
trans-unit.target: Contributing to PowerShell Documentation

trans-unit.source: Sign a CLA
trans-unit.target: Sign a CLA

trans-unit.source: Before you can contribute to any PowerShell repositories, you must [sign a Microsoft Contribution Licensing Agreement (CLA)](https://cla.microsoft.com/).
trans-unit.target: Before you can contribute to any PowerShell repositories, you must [sign a Microsoft Contribution Licensing Agreement (CLA)](https://cla.microsoft.com/).

trans-unit.source: If you've already contributed to PowerShell repostories in the past, congratulations!
trans-unit.target: If you've already contributed to PowerShell repostories in the past, congratulations!

trans-unit.source: You've already completed this step.
trans-unit.target: You've already completed this step.

trans-unit.source: Writing PowerShell documentation
trans-unit.target: Writing PowerShell documentation

trans-unit.source: One of the easiest ways to contribute to PowerShell is by helping to write and edit documentation.
trans-unit.target: One of the easiest ways to contribute to PowerShell is by helping to write and edit documentation.

trans-unit.source: All of our documentation hosted on GitHub is written using [GitHub Flavored Markdown](https://help.github.com/articles/github-flavored-markdown/).
trans-unit.target: All of our documentation hosted on GitHub is written using [GitHub Flavored Markdown](https://help.github.com/articles/github-flavored-markdown/).

trans-unit.source: To [edit an existing file](https://help.github.com/articles/editing-files-in-another-user-s-repository/), simply navigate to it and click the "Edit" button.
trans-unit.target: To [edit an existing file](https://help.github.com/articles/editing-files-in-another-user-s-repository/), simply navigate to it and click the "Edit" button.

trans-unit.source: GitHub will automatically create your own fork of our repository where you can make your changes.
trans-unit.target: GitHub will automatically create your own fork of our repository where you can make your changes.

trans-unit.source: Once you're finished, save your edits and submit a pull request to get your changes merged upstream.
trans-unit.target: Once you're finished, save your edits and submit a pull request to get your changes merged upstream.

trans-unit.source: After your pull request is created,
trans-unit.target: After your pull request is created,

trans-unit.source: If you want to contribute new documentation, first check for [issues tagged as "in progress"](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell-Docs/labels/in%20progress) to make sure you're not duplicating efforts.
trans-unit.target: If you want to contribute new documentation, first check for [issues tagged as "in progress"](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell-Docs/labels/in%20progress) to make sure you're not duplicating efforts.

trans-unit.source: If no one seems to be working on what you have planned:
trans-unit.target: If no one seems to be working on what you have planned:

trans-unit.source: Open a new issue tagged as "in progress" to tell others what you're working on
trans-unit.target: Open a new issue tagged as "in progress" to tell others what you're working on

trans-unit.source: Create a fork of our repository and start adding new Markdown-based documentation to it
trans-unit.target: Create a fork of our repository and start adding new Markdown-based documentation to it

trans-unit.source: When you're ready to contribute your documentation, submit a pull request to the *master* branch
trans-unit.target: When you're ready to contribute your documentation, submit a pull request to the *master* branch

trans-unit.source: GitHub Flavored Markdown (GFM)
trans-unit.target: GitHub Flavored Markdown (GFM)

trans-unit.source: All of the articles in this repository use [GitHub Flavored Markdown (GFM)](https://help.github.com/articles/github-flavored-markdown/).
trans-unit.target: All of the articles in this repository use [GitHub Flavored Markdown (GFM)](https://help.github.com/articles/github-flavored-markdown/).

trans-unit.source: If you are looking for a good editor, try [Markdown Pad](http://markdownpad.com/) or GitHub also provides a web interface for Markdown editing with syntax highlighting and the ability to preview changes.
trans-unit.target: If you are looking for a good editor, try [Markdown Pad](http://markdownpad.com/) or GitHub also provides a web interface for Markdown editing with syntax highlighting and the ability to preview changes.

trans-unit.source: Some of the more basic GFM syntax includes:
trans-unit.target: Some of the more basic GFM syntax includes:

trans-unit.source:
**Line breaks vs. paragraphs:** In Markdown there is no HTML `
` or `

` element.
trans-unit.target:
**Line breaks vs. paragraphs:** In Markdown there is no HTML `
` or `

` element.

trans-unit.source: Instead, a new paragraph is designated by an empty line between two blocks of text.
trans-unit.target: Instead, a new paragraph is designated by an empty line between two blocks of text.

trans-unit.source: **Note**: Please add a single newline after each sentence to simplify the command-line output of diffs and history.
trans-unit.target: **Note**: Please add a single newline after each sentence to simplify the command-line output of diffs and history.

trans-unit.source: This is not currently adopted across all of PowerShell-Docs, but we will be working towards it over time.
trans-unit.target: This is not currently adopted across all of PowerShell-Docs, but we will be working towards it over time.

trans-unit.source: Feel free to help out.
trans-unit.target: Feel free to help out.

trans-unit.source: **Italics:** The HTML `some text` is written as
trans-unit.target: **Italics:** The HTML `some text` is written as

trans-unit.source: **Bold:** The HTML `some text` element is written as
trans-unit.target: **Bold:** The HTML `some text` element is written as

trans-unit.source: **Headings:** HTML headings are designated using `#` characters at the start of the line.
trans-unit.target: **Headings:** HTML headings are designated using `#` characters at the start of the line.

trans-unit.source: The number of `#` characters corresponds to the hierarchical level of the heading (for example, `#` = `<h1>` and `###` = ```<h3>```).
trans-unit.target: The number of `#` characters corresponds to the hierarchical level of the heading (for example, `#` = `<h1>` and `###` = ```<h3>```).

trans-unit.source: **Numbered lists:** To make a numbered (ordered) list start the line with `1. `.
trans-unit.target: **Numbered lists:** To make a numbered (ordered) list start the line with `1. `.

trans-unit.source: If you want multiple elements within a single list element, format your list as follows:
trans-unit.target: If you want multiple elements within a single list element, format your list as follows:

trans-unit.source: to get this output:
trans-unit.target: to get this output:

trans-unit.source: For the first element (like this one), insert a tab stop after the 1.
trans-unit.target: For the first element (like this one), insert a tab stop after the 1.

trans-unit.source: To include a second element (like this one), insert a line break after the first and align indentations.
trans-unit.target: To include a second element (like this one), insert a line break after the first and align indentations.

trans-unit.source: **Bulleted lists:** Bulleted (unordered) lists are almost identical to ordered lists except that the `1. ` is replaced with either `* `, `- `, or `+ `.
trans-unit.target: **Bulleted lists:** Bulleted (unordered) lists are almost identical to ordered lists except that the `1. ` is replaced with either `* `, `- `, or `+ `.

trans-unit.source: Multiple element lists work the same way as with ordered lists.
trans-unit.target: Multiple element lists work the same way as with ordered lists.

trans-unit.source: **Links:** The syntax for a hyperlink is `[visible link text](link url)`.
trans-unit.target: **Links:** The syntax for a hyperlink is `[visible link text](link url)`.

trans-unit.source: Links can also have references, which will be discussed in the "Link and Image References" section below.
trans-unit.target: Links can also have references, which will be discussed in the "Link and Image References" section below.
